title: Abortion
desc: A surgical procedure to terminate an established pregnancy by emptying the uterus (or womb) with special instruments within a clinical setting. The alternative to surgical abortion is a medical abortion and is brought about by taking medications that will end a pregnancy. Either of two medications, mifepristone or methotrexate, can be used for medical abortion. Both types of abortion must be done by a certified health professional.

title: Child
desc: A young human being, often described as a minor, below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majorityusually 18 years or as defined by the country in which the child resides in.

title: Child Marriage
desc: Early marriage, or child marriage, is defined as the marriage or union between two people in which one or both parties are younger than stipulated legal age of marriage in the country of citizenry or residence. Child marriages are often �arranged� by parents or guardian and is termed forced marriage.

title: Chromosomes
desc:
A thread like strand of DNA in the cell nucleus that carries the genes in a linear order. In most cells, human have 22pairs of these chromosomes plus two sex chromosomes � XX in females and XY in males for a total of 46 (occasional cases more or less). 
In the XY sex-determination system, the female-provided ovum (egg) contributes an X chromosome and the male-provided sperm contributes either an X chromosomeor a Y chromosome, resulting in female (XX) or male (XY) offspring, respectively. Sometimes, there are natural exceptions to this rule and such persons are recognised as intersex.

title: Cisgender
desc: Denoting or relating to a person whose sense of personal identity and gender corresponds with their given birth sex. Cisgender is the most common of gender and is opposite of transgenderand represents the majority subculture in the genderclassification.

title: Consent
Contraception
desc:
The deliberate use of contraceptives which is an artificial device or a drug that can be safely used to prevent (contra) pregnancy (conception), also known as birth or fertility control.   There are about 15 types of contraceptives. The major methods of artificial contraception are: 
Barrier methods, of which the commonest is the male and female condom or sheath which protects from STItoo.
Contraceptive pill, which contains synthetic sex hormones which prevent ovulation in the female; 
Intrauterine devices, such as the coil, which prevent the fertilized ovum from implanting in the uterus; 
Injectable and implants, utilise artificial progesterone (progestin). One shot of hormones lasts in the body for 8 to 12 weeks (3 months) and has the same effect as the pill.
Permanent method such as male or female sterilization, is the most effective of methods. It is reversible in males within a 10 year period.
Emergency contraceptionor the �morning after pill� is to stop pregnancy if there has been unprotected sex or contraception used after the fact. This method is only for one-off occasions and is not recommended for daily use or repeated use. It is particularly useful if a condom accidently broke or if you missed one of your contraceptive pills. It is a pill to be used in exception and not as a rule.

title: Denial of Resources, Opportunities or Services
desc: Denial of rightful access to economic resources/assets or livelihood opportunities, education, health or other social services. It is a category within Gender Based Violence and Violence against Women. Examples of denial include a widow prevented from receiving an inheritance, earnings forcibly taken by an intimate partner or family member, a woman prevented from using contraceptives, a girl prevented from attending school, a disabled person denied help or forcibly kept hidden or inheritance taken etc.

title: Domestic Violence
desc:
All acts of physical, sexual, psychological or economic violence within the family or domestic unit or between former or current spouses or partners, whether or not the perpetrator shares or has shared the same residence with the victim. 
"Domestic Violence" means any form of physical, mental, sexual and economic harm perpetrated by person to a person with whom he/she has a family relationship and this word also includes any acts of reprimand or emotional harm. www.lawcommission.gov.np
The two main forms of domestic violence are: 
Intimate partner violence: Includes behaviour by current or former spouses or partners that causes physical, sexual or psychological harm and abuse, including acts of physical aggression, sexual coercion, marital rape and psychological abuse and controlling behaviours.
Inter-generational violence:Or family violence, typically occurs between parents, guardians and children that causes physical, sexual or psychological harm and abuse, including acts of physical aggression, sexual coercion, and psychological abuse and controlling behaviours. If under age this form of violence is categorised as Child abuse
(1) A person who commits an act of domestic violence shall be punished with a fine of Three Thousand Rupees upto Twenty Five Thousand Rupees or Six months of imprisonment or both. (2) A person who attempts to commit domestic violence or abets the crime or incites others to commit the crime shall be liable to half the punishment of the perpetrator. (3) A person who has been punished once for the offence of domestic violence shall be liable to double the punishment upon every repetition of the offence. (4) If a person holing a public post who commits the offence of domestic violence, he/she shall be liable to an additional ten percent punishment.

title: DNA
desc: Your DNA is what makes you uniquely you. It's that double helix (an object shaped like a spiral) that your genes are made of. DNA is the chemical basis of heredity.Your DNA accounts for why you resemble your parents. It could give you, your Dad�s funny nose you really didn�t want and your mom�s piercing dark eyes that makes the girls (or boys) swoon; it distinguishes you from your pet frog and from everybody else.DNA stands for deoxyribonucleic acid, a mouthful as all scientific terms tend to be. So let�s callit "the molecule of life," as almost all organisms have their genetic material codified as DNA. Since each person�s DNA is unique, "DNA typing" is a valuable tool in connecting suspects to crime scenes. You can also use the word less scientifically, as in �It�s just not in my DNA to sit through hours and hours of meetingsevery day and call it work, I need a life!�

title: Empowerment
desc: It literally means to give power and authority to a person or more positively to give strength and confidence to someone who needs it. In tackling VAW or GBV, it is the process of helping girls and women, boys and men, and anyone who feels excluded or at a loss, to be more in control of their lives and able to take decisions about their future. For e.g. battered women are not �sick�, rather they are in a �sick situation� and responses need to demonstrate an understanding, and take into account, their differing needs as an individual first and foremost and part of a social unit for support, advocacy and healing. Empowerment is a key feature of advocacy interventions and of some psychological (brief counselling) interventions

title: Female Foeticide
desc: Is the practice of aborting a foetus when a personfinds out that the foetus is femaleafter undergoing a sex determination test known as prenatal diagnostic tests.

title: Female genital mutilation
desc: Female genital mutilation (FGM) comprises all procedures that involve partial or total removal of the external female genitalia, or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons.

title: Female infanticide
desc: Is the twin of female foeticide and entails the deliberate killing of girl babies. It is also described as gender-selective killing or "gendercide".

title: Forced abortion
desc: A forced abortion may occur when a perpetrator causes abortion by force, threat or coercion, or by taking advantage of a woman's incapability to give her consent, or where she gives her consent under duress.

title: Forced Marriage
desc: The marriageof a person against her or his will (no consent) at any age by any person known or unknown.The marriage is forced if at least one of the two in the union has not given his/her full and free consent. As prescribed by tradition and culture, even if parents and guardians of both sides are in agreement and marriages are arranged, consent of the person being married still apply.

title: Forced pregnancy
desc: Forced pregnancy is the practice of forcing a woman to become pregnant, often as part of a forced marriage. When a forced pregnancy leads to reproduction, it is a form of reproductive coercion which in traditional cultures can be overt but very often it is subtle, borne mostly by young married women in Nepal.

title: Forced sterilization
desc: Forced sterilization is the process of permanently ending someone's ability to reproduce without his or her consent.

title: Gender
desc: Gender:Firstly,growing up as a member of the most common biological group-male or female � a binary label for sex categorisation assigned at birth based onlyon the outward look of the �normal� genitalia (penis and vagina). Secondly, along the way the same biological male and female acquire prescribed states of masculine and femininebehaviour traits (with due reference to social, religiousor cultural differences) and end up being accepted as a man or a woman by themselves, family, community and society and all the expectations therein.

title: Genes
desc:
Microscopic, yet powerful, a gene is segment of DNA (or gene contains DNA), the molecule that stores the code for building living bodies and a unit of hereditary, passed on over generations.Gene was shortened from "pan-gene" which means "all-generation".
A gene is a single unit of genetic information, stored on twisting strands in every cell of every living being. In sexual reproduction, the parents' genes mix together to make the child. Although people would like to think that genes code for discrete traits, like friendliness or mathematical genius, that's not the case. Genes control the colour of your eyes and the shape of your toes, not your weird personality.

title: Gender Based Violence
desc: Gender Based Violence Or GBV is the term used to capture violence that generally occurs as a result of the customary or standard role expectations associated with each sex (born male and female), along with the unequal power relationships between the two genders (being a man or a woman), within the context of a specific society and its level of development.These days many countries Nepal is one have ruled GBV (boy, girl, man, woman and LGBTI) as an act of the human rights violation. There is no consent in this form of violence. Almost all harmful traditional practices are considered to be GBV or VAW, hence criminal, subject to legal punishment if reported.

title: Gender biased sex selection
desc: Sex-selection in favour of boys may take place before a pregnancy is established, during pregnancy through prenatal sex detection and selective abortion, or following birth through infanticide or child neglect. Pre-natal sex selection refers to the practice of using medical techniques to choose the sex of offspring that is to be born. This term �sex selection� encompasses a number of practices including selecting embryos for transfer and implantation following in vitro fertilization, separating sperm, and selectively terminating a pregnancy.

title: Gender Discrimination
desc: A situation in which someone is treated less well because of their sex, usually when a girl or woman is treated less well than a boy or man.

title: Gender Identity and gender expression
desc:
Instead, the understanding of these and other related terms such as LGBTI, and the implications for policies, is evolving from tribunal and court decisions, social science research as well as self-identity and common everyday use: 
Gender identity is each person�s internal and individual experience of gender. It is a person�s sense of being a woman, a man, both, neither, or anywhere along the gender spectrum. A person�s gender identity may be the same as or different from their birth-assigned sex.
Gender expression is how a person publicly expresses or presents their gender. This can include behaviour and outward appearance such as dress, hair, make-up, body language and voice. A person�s chosen name and pronoun are also common ways of expressing gender. Others perceive a person�s gender through these attributes.
�Lived� gender identity is the gender a person feels internally (�gender identity� along the gender spectrum) and expresses publicly (�gender expression�) in their daily life including at work, while shopping or accessing other services, in their housing environment or in the broader community.
A person�s gender identity is fundamentally different from and not related to their sexual orientation.

title: Harmful Traditional Practices
desc: All practices done deliberately and often by men and sometimes with support of women on the body or the psyche (mental health) of girls and other women (in most cases) for no therapeutic purpose, but rather for cultural or socio-traditional and conventional motives and which have harmful consequences on the safety, security, health and the rights of the girl orwoman. Examples of harmful practices that can come under the remit of GBV or VAW include child marriage, forced marriage, virginity testing,widowhood rites,elder abuse, sex trafficking, forced pregnancy or reproductive coercion,  female genital mutilation/cutting, �honour� killings, gender-biased sex-selection� female foeticide ,infanticideetc. These harmful acts are considered forms of violence and often illegal.

title: Health-care provider
desc: An individual or an organization that provides health-care services in a systematic way. An individual health-care provider may be a health-care professional, a community health worker, or any other social care or social protection person who is trained and knowledgeable in health. This can include lay health-care workers who have received some training to deliver care in their community. Organizations include hospitals, clinics, primary care centres and other services delivery points. In these guidelines, the term �health-care provider� usually refers to the primary care provider (nurse, midwife, doctor or other).

title: Health system
desc: A health system is the sum total of all the organizations, institutions and resources whose primary purpose is to improve health of the nation. A health system needs staff, funds, information, supplies, transport, communications and overall guidance and direction to provide services that are responsive and financially fair, while treating people decently. A good health delivers quality of care to all people, when and where they need them. The exact configuration of services varies from country to country, but in all cases requires a robust financing mechanism; a well-trained and adequately paid workforce; reliable information on which to base decisions and policies; well-maintained facilities and logistics to deliver quality medicines and technologies. In Nepal we have 2 forms of health system:Public and Private Health (for profit and not-for profit),

title: Honour killings
desc: A harmful traditional practice in which women and girls suspected of defiling their family's honour by their �misconduct� can be killed by their brother, father, uncle or another relative who thus restores the said honour. Honour killings are executed for instances of rape, infidelity, flirting or any other instance perceived as disgracing the family's honour, and the woman is then killed by a male relative to restore the family's name in the community. The allegation of misconduct alone is considered enough to defile a man's or family's honour, and is therefore enough to justify the killing of the woman. The men who commit the murder typically go unpunished or receive reduced sentences and is on the rise in Nepal.

title: Human Trafficking
desc: It ismodern-day slavery and involves the use of force, fraud, or coercion to obtain some exploitative type of labour or commercial sex act. Trafficked people are susceptible for a variety of reasons, including psychological or emotional vulnerability, economic hardship,and lack of a social safety net, natural disasters, or political instability. The trauma caused by the traffickers can be so great that many may not identify themselves as victims or ask for help, even in highly public settings.  Human trafficking is a hidden crime as victims of such violence rarely come forward to seek help because of language barriers, fear of the traffickers, and/or even fear of law enforcement.

title: Intersex
desc: A general term used for a variety of conditions in which a person is born with a reproductive or sexual anatomy that doesnot seem to fit the typical binary definitions of female (vagina) or male (penis).There are several intersex variations based on chromosome and external and internal genital diversity, as such, it is an umbrella term rather than a single category. Contrary to myth, an inter-sexual person does not have two sets of genitals; rather they often have ambiguous genital structures not readily identifiable as clitoris/penis or labia/scrotum. Again, the previous sentence, is not necessarily true, and intersex people have sometimes gone for long periods of their lives without knowing that they were intersex, for they outwardly look no different to any male/man or female/woman. They may internally have gonads of mixed ovarian tissue, testicular and ovarian. They may have unusual chromosomes, for example a mosaic of XX and XY cells in their body.

title: Incest
desc: Is sexual activity between family members or close blood relatives. This typically includes sexual activity between people in a consanguineous relationship (blood relations), and sometimes those related by affinity, such as individuals of the same household, stepfamily, those related by adoption or marriage, or members of the same clan or lineage. Within the sphere of GBV, incest is classified as non-consensual sexual relations between close family members and hence categorized as violence. However, there are cultural differences in what is considered incest and what is permitted.

title: Intervention
desc: Any action undertaken with the aim to eliminate GBV/VAW and harmful traditional practices. Interventions can be preventive or reactive and can have different formats, such as laws, policies, large-scale programmes, or single projects. In the context of health system responses to GBV, interventions are understood as any actions set by health care professionals vis-�-vis a survivor of GBV, aimed at identifying GBV, providing first-line support and other medical care as well as referring the survivor to other services.

title: Isolation
desc: A form of psychological/emotional violence.  Perpetrators often try to control survivors� time, activities and contact with others. They gain control over them through a combination of isolating and disinformation tactics. Isolating tactics may become more overtly abusive over time. Through incremental isolation, some perpetrators increase their psychological control to the point where they determine reality for the survivors. Perpetrators� use of disinformation tactics such as distorting what is real through lying, providing contradictory information, or withholding information is compounded by the forced isolation of the survivors.

title: Legal age of consent
desc: It is the age at which a person is considered by the state to be legally competent to consent to sexual acts, and is thus the minimum age of a person with whom another person is legally permitted to engage in sexual activity.Individuals aged 15 or younger in Nepal are not legally able to consent to sexual activity, and such activity may result in prosecution for statutory rape or the equivalent local law. Nepal statutory rape law is violated when an individual has consensual sexual contact with a person under age 16.

title: Legal age of marriage
desc:
Marriageable age (or marriage age) is the minimum age at which a person is allowed by law to marry, become husband and wife either as a right or subject to parental or other forms of consent.

The legal age of marriage is 20 for both men and women, according to the Nepalese Country Code.
The law states that punishment for child marriage is imprisonment for up to three years and a fine of up to 10,000 rupees (�102).

title: Legal age of majority
desc: Age at which a person, formerly a minor is recognised by law to be an adult, capable of managing his or her own affairs and responsible for any legal obligations created by his or her actions.

title: LGBTI
desc:
Is an acronym for:
Lesbian: term used to describe someone who identifies as femaleand attracted to others who identify as female.
Gay: termused to describe someone who identifies as male and is attracted to others who identify as male.
Bisexual:  term used to describe someone who is attracted to others of the same sex and those of different sex.
Trans:Trans is a blanket term that can be used in many different ways. Some people use it to indicate that their gender identity is not the same as the gender they were assigned at birth. . It is also used for some of the following words as well; Transgender, Transsexual, Transitioning, Transman, Transwoman.
Intersex: word used to describe people who are both with atypical sex characteristics that lie between stereotypical definitions of male and female. There are many different forms of intersexvariations, as such, it is an umbrella term rather than a single category.Many Intersex people look no different to anyone else.
Knowing and understanding what all the letters of the LGBTI mean can be tricky.Depending on the culture and country, LGBTI may have different letters and meanings. More and more alphabets are being added to it. You may see LGBTIQQ  
Queer: Originally a term used in a derogatory sense, many LGBTI youth have embraced this word and given it a rebirth. It can be described as a broad umbrella term for anyone who may identify as being either gender, sexually and/or bodily diverse or genderqueer.
Questioning: Someone who is in the process of exploring their own sexuality and/or gender. It may involve experimentation and looking into one�s own family, cultural and religious history in the process.

title: Mandatory reporting
desc: Mandatory reporting Refers to legislation passed by some countries or states that requires individuals or designated individuals such as health-care providers to report (usually to the police or legal system) any incident of actual or suspected trafficking and domestic violence or intimate partner violence. In many countries, mandatory reporting applies primarily to child abuse and maltreatment of minors, but in others it has been extended to the reporting of intimate partner violence.

title: Marriage
desc:
The formal and legal union of a man and a woman by which they become husband and wife. This union has been increasingly extended to other genders (LGBTI) in some countries. 
-Monogamy: Union of one man and one woman. This form of marriage allows a man to marry only one woman at a given time. The practice is well accepted worldwide because of its advantages. In Nepal, monogamy is the accepted legal form of marriage.
-Polygamy: One person marries two or more persons of the opposite sex at the same time. This is commonly known as multiple marriages.
-Bigamy:"Bigamy" means to marry with another woman by a husband even he has a wife and to marry with another man by a wife even she has a husband.
-Polyandry:A practice in which women have two or more husbands at the same time. A rare form of polygamy, polyandry is practiced by only a few cultures, such as in Far Western Nepal among particular indigenous mountain people

title: Matriarchy
desc: a system of society in which the eldest woman or women, mother is the head of family and descent is reckoned through the female line. History does have such instances of lineage, state and government of being an older, powerful woman in a family or group. The use of the term has grown incrementally after 1900 especially as the demand by women for women for human rights, voting rights, emancipation and participation has come to the forefront of societal change.

title: Misogyny
desc: Typically an unconscious hatred that men form early in life, often as a result of trauma involving a female figure they were close to and trusted. It could be a mother, sister, female relative, teacher, colleague, wife or girlfriend. A misogynist dislikes, despises, or is strongly prejudiced against women and often unable to rationalise the feeling.  Often called a woman � hater, anti- feminist, male chauvinist, male supremacist, chauvinist, sexist male, male chauvinist pig or MCP

title: Myth
desc: Is a widely held but false belief or idea with or without a determinable basis of fact or a natural explanation. Often myths are concerned with deities or demigods and explains some human practice, rite, or phenomenon of nature. For the source culture a myth by definition is "true", in that it embodies beliefs, concepts and ways of questioning to make sense of the world. A myth is also a well-known story which was made up in the past to explain natural events or to justify religious beliefs or social customs and is not based in scientific fact. E.g. Men think of sex every 7 seconds, Blondes have all the fun, Immaculate Conception (and no help of technology).

title: No consent
Patriarchy
desc: A system of society in which the father or eldest male is head of the family and descent is reckoned through the male line. Often this manifests itself in social, economic and political norms organised on patriarchal lines in which men hold the power and women are largely excluded from it. The use of the term has grown over a hundred fold after the gender became an inherent part of social discourse and development change.

title: Physical Assault
desc: an act of physical violence that is not sexual in nature. Examples include: hitting, slapping, choking, cutting, shoving, burning, shooting or use of any weapons, acid attacks or any other act that results in pain, discomfort or injury. This incident type does not include FGM/C.

title: Psychological / Emotional Abuse
desc: infliction of mental or emotional pain or injury. Examples include: threats of physical or sexual violence, intimidation, humiliation, forced isolation, stalking, verbal harassment, unwanted attention, remarks, gestures or written words of a sexual and/or menacing nature, destruction of cherished things, etc.

title: Perpetrator
desc: A person, group, or institution that directly inflicts, supports and/or condones violence and abuse against a person or a group of persons.

title: Physical violence
desc: The use of physical force that results in bodily injury, pain, or impairment. The severity of injury ranges from minimal tissue damage, broken bones to permanent injury and death. Acts of physical violence include: slapping, shoving, pushing, punching, beating, scratching, choking, biting, grabbing, shaking, spitting, burning, twisting of a body part, forcing the ingestion of an unwanted substance; restraining a woman to prevent her from seeking medical treatment or other help; and using household objects to hit or stab a woman, using weapons like knives or guns

title: Post-traumatic stress disorder
desc: PTSD may develop after a person is exposed to one or more traumatic events, such as sexual assault, serious injury, or the threat of death. The diagnosis may be given when a group of symptoms, such as disturbing recurring flashbacks, avoidance or numbing of memories of the event, and hyper arousal continue for more than a month after the traumatic event.

title: Prenatal sex selection
desc: Prenatal sex selection is the attempt to control the sex of the offspring to achieve a desired sex. Under the mantle of GBV, prenatal sex selection usually refers to the favouring of male children over female children.

title: Prostitution
desc: The business practice or occupation of engaging in sexual activity (may or may not include sexual intercourse) with someone for payment. Prostitution is often consensual between two or more adults, if regulatedis described as sex work.  On the other hand non-consensual prostitution through sex trafficking is always illegal

title: Psychological violence
desc: An action or set of actions that directly impair the woman�s psychological integrity. Acts of psychological violence include: threats of violence and harm against the woman or somebody close to her, through words or actions (e.g. through stalking or displaying weapons); harassment and mobbing at the work place; humiliating and insulting comments; isolation and restrictions on communication (e.g. through locking her up in the house, forcing her to quit her job or prohibiting her from seeing a doctor); and use of children by a violent intimate partner to control or hurt the woman (e.g. through attacking a child, forcing children to watch attacks against their mother, threatening to take children away, or kidnapping the child). These acts constitute both, violence against children as well as violence against women

title: Prevalence
desc: The number of persons having a specific characteristic or problem, divided by the number of persons in the study population who are considered to be at risk of having the problem, usually expressed as a percentage.

title: Prevalence study
desc: In the context of GBV or VAW, prevalence studies seek to measure the scope of GBV. Usually, prevalence research is undertaken through population-based surveys. These surveys use randomly selected samples; therefore, their results are representative of the larger population (UN Secretary-General 2006).

title: Pregnancy
desc:
Also known as gestation, is the time during which one or more offspring develops inside a woman. The period from conception to birth. After the egg is fertilized by a sperm and then implanted in the lining of the uterus, itdevelops into the placenta and embryo, and later into a fetus. Pregnancy usually lasts 40 weeks, 
beginning from the firstday of the woman's last menstrual period, and is divided into three trimesters, each lasting three monthsA multiple pregnancy involves more than one offspring, such as with twins. Pregnancy can occur by sexual intercourse or assisted reproductive technology.

title: Rape
desc:
Physically forced or otherwise coerced penetration of the vulva, vagina or anus with a penis (non-consensual sexual intercourse), other body part, or object, although the legal definition of rape may vary and, in some cases, may also include oral (mouth) penetration:
Statutory Rape: (in some jurisdictions) sexual intercourse with a minor. Criminal offense of statutory rape is committed when an adult sexually penetrates a person who, under the law, isincapable of consenting to sex. Minors and physically and mentally incapacitated persons are deemed incapable ofconsenting to sex under rape statutes in all states. These persons are considered deserving of special protection becausethey are especially vulnerable due to their youth or condition.
Marital Rape: rape committed by the person to whom the victim is/was married. It means any unwanted sexual acts by a spouse or ex-spouse that is committed without the other person's consent. Such illegal sexual activity are done using force, threat of force, intimidation, or when a person is unable to consent. The sexual acts include intercourse, anal or oral sex, forced sexual behaviour with other individuals, and other sexual activities that are considered by the victim as degrading, humiliating, painful, and unwanted. It is also known as spousal rape.
Systematic Rape: also known as, war rape, are rapes committed by soldiers, other combatants or civilians during armed conflict or war, or during military occupation. It also covers the situation where girls and women are forced into prostitution or sexual slavery by an occupying power.

title: Referral
desc: The process of how a woman gets in touch with an individual professional or institution about her case and how professionals and institutions communicate and work together to provide her with comprehensive support. Partners in a referral network usually include different government departments, women�s organizations, community organizations, medical institutions and others.

title: Referral system
desc: A comprehensive institutional framework that connects various entities with well-defined and delineated (albeit in some cases overlapping) mandates, responsibilities and powers into a network of cooperation, with the overall aim of ensuring the protection and assistance of survivors, to aid in their full recovery and empowerment, the prevention of GBV and the prosecution of perpetrators (the so-called 3 p�s). Referral mechanisms work on the basis of efficient lines of communication and establish clearly outlined referral pathways and procedures, with clear and simple sequential steps.

title: Service
desc: The action of helping or doing work for someone.A service is something that the public needs. The public system supplies a public need such as health care, social care, social protection, transport, communications, or utilities such as electricity and water.

title: Sex
desc: There are several meanings to this word. 1) Either of the two main categories (male or female) into which humans and most living things such as animal and plants are divided on the basis of their reproductive functions. 2) The fact of being male or female, all the gender attributes by which males and females are distinguished as masculine and feminine, man and woman.  3) The group of all members of either sexmale or female or more � inter-sex, trans. 4) Sexual intercourse

title: Sexual Assault
desc: A subcategory of sexual violence, sexual assault usually includes the use of physical or other force to obtain or attempt sexual penetration.).any form of no consent (non-consensual) sexual contact that does not result in or include penetration. Examples include: attempted rape, as well as unwanted kissing, fondling, or touching of genitalia and buttocks. FGM/C is an act of violence that impacts sexual organs, and as such should be classified as sexual assault. This incident type does not include rape, i.e., where penetration has occurred.

title: Sex of foetus/baby
desc: Sperm from the man dictates the sex of the fertilized egg from the woman. However, a lot of mutual factors contribute to determining sex of the baby, including as the egg's receptivity to the male's chromosomes. The chance of it being a boy or a girl is 50/50, so neither the man nor woman is to blame.

title: Sexual Intercourse
desc: sexual contact between individuals involving penetration. This can be heterosexual intercourse involving penetration of the vagina by an erect penis or coitus. Or it can be anal or oral intercourse that does not involve penetration of the vagina by the penis. Intercourse typically culminates in orgasm and the ejaculation of semen.

title: Sexual Exploitation
desc: is the sexual abuse of children and youth through the exchange of sex or sexual acts for drugs, food, shelter, protection, other basics of life, and/or money. Sexual exploitation includes involving children and youth in creating pornography and sexually explicit websites.

title: Sexual harassment
desc: Any form of unwanted verbal, non-verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature, with the purpose or effect of violating the dignity of a person, in particular when creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment. At the work place, sexual harassment often takes two forms: when the harasser makes a job benefit - such as a pay rise, a promotion, or even continued employment - conditional on the person acceding to demands to engage in some form of sexual behaviour; or when the harasser�s conduct creates a hostile and intimidating working environment for the person concerned.

title: Sexual orientation
desc:
Is a term used to describe an individual�s patterns of emotional, romantic, and sexual attraction�and their sense of personal and social identity based on those attractions. A person's sexual orientation is not a black or white matter; sexual orientation exists along a continuum, with exclusive attraction to the opposite sex on one end of the continuum and exclusive attraction to the same sex on the other. 
Three most commonly discussed categories of sexual orientation are heterosexual, homosexual and bisexual, though are by no means the only categories in the world of sexual identification labels.
Heterosexuality: Attraction to members of the opposite sex, 
Homosexuality:Attraction to members of the same sex, label themselves �gay�, women are referred to as Lesbian
Bisexuality: Attraction to members of either sex
Asexuality: Little or no interest in sex and/or sexual attraction to others. They may pursue romantic interests without any sexual behaviour involved, sometimes label themselves as ACE.This is very different to celibacy or chastity which is a choice.
Pansexuality: This is someone who experiences both romantic and sexual attraction for all genders and gender expressions. They often do not see people being defined as either male or female, accepting individuals based off their personality, emotional and/or spiritual characteristics.This is not the same as bisexuality.
Nepal is one of the most progressive countries in not only South Asia, but also globally for LGBTI rights as the country has recognized LGBTI rights as being fundamental in its 2015 constitution. Nepal's current LGBTI laws are some of the most open in the world and expand upon a multitude of rights for LGBTI identified Nepalese. Implementation of these is making slow progress.

title: Sexual Slavery
desc: Is slavery for the purpose of sexual exploitation. Sexual slavery may involve single-owner sexual slavery; ritual slavery, sometimes associated with certain religious practices; slavery for primarily non-sexual purposes but where non-consensual sexual activity is common; or forced prostitution.

title: Sex work
desc: The provision of sexual services for money or goods. Sex workers are women, men, intersex and transgendered people who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, and who consciously define those activities as income generating even if they do not consider sex work as their occupation.Prostitution and sex work are connected but the difference between them matters. They are both legally regulated to varying degrees in most countries. Think of sex work as the legal and often tax paying branch of prostitution. This includes adult entertainment (Cam work, porn star, exotic dance and phone sex), escort agencies, brothels and massage parlours.

title: Sexual violence
desc: Any sexual act, attempt to obtain a sexual act, unwanted sexual comments or advances, or acts to traffic, or otherwise directed against a person�s sexuality, using coercion, by any person, regardless of their relationship to the victim, in any setting, including, but not limited to, home and work.

title: Socio-Economic Status
desc: Is the social standing or class of an individual or group. It is often measured as a combination of education, income and occupation.

title: Suicides
desc: Following experiences of domestic violence, taking ones life suicides committed by women to escape violence and oppression, sometimes prompted by pressure from family members for in adherence to �proper� or �honourable� conduct. In some cases, recorded suicide cases may also be disguised murders.

title: Son preference
desc: Son preference refers to an attitude founded on the belief that girls are inadequate and of lesser value than boys. As a major form of gender discrimination, it can give way to an array of practices harmful to girls and women. For instance, neglect of the girl child in terms of withholding access to health, education, economic opportunity and in some cases even food and other basic necessities. In an alternative form, son preference has also manifested itself through the practice of sex selective abortion. In gender research, son preference is said to be rooted in discriminatory religious and cultural norms but most importantly in unequal laws between men and women in terms of inheritance and civil rights.

title: Survivor/victim
desc: Often refers to a woman or girl who has experienced any form of GBV. International law defines �victim� as �any natural person who is subject to [violence against women or domestic violence]�. Both terms are often used synonymously. In order to underline that women and girls who experienced violence are not �passive� victims but are actively trying to stop violence and seeking protection and support, the present publication uses the term �survivor�, with the exception of references to terminology used in international human rights standards or context-specific terminology (for instance when referring to homicide).

title: Threats of violence and harm
desc: The perpetrator�s threats of violence or harm may be directed against the survivor or others important to the survivor or they may be suicide threats. Sometimes the threat includes killing the victim and others and then committing suicide. The threats may be made directly with words (e.g., �I�m going to kill you,� �No one is going to have you,� �Your mother is going to pay,� �I cannot live without you�) or with actions (e.g., stalking, displaying weapons, hostage taking, suicide attempts).

title: Trafficking in women
desc: (The UN publication uses the term "trafficking in person" but due to the main focus of the app the term "trafficking in women is used"). The recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of a woman, by means of the threat or use of force or other forms of coercion, of abduction, of fraud, of deception, of the abuse of power or of a position of vulnerability or of the giving or receiving of payments or benefits to achieve the consent of a person having control over a woman, for the purpose of exploitation. Exploitation shall include, at a minimum, the exploitation of the prostitution of others or other forms of sexual exploitation, forced labour or services, slavery or practices similar to slavery, servitude or the removal of organs. The recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of a child for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered �trafficking in persons� even if this does not involve any of the coercive means listed above (adapted from UN 2000).

title: Transactional Sex
desc: Sexual relationships where the giving of gifts or services is an important factor.The term became important in the prevention of HIV, in cultures where young girls were married to old men. In exchange the girl�s family received gifts and cash.

title: Transgender
desc:
Is an umbrella term relating to, or being a person whose gender identity and expressionis opposite from the sex the person was assigned to or was identified as having at birth. Transgender, includesa diverse range of people, each a distinct sub-category.  
Transman and Transwoman: The term transman is commonly referred to as someone is born with female genital but identifies as male (F2M) and transwoman has male genital but identifies as female. In short, their sex organ (male, female) does not reflect their gender (man, woman). The two may also identify as the lesser used term, transsexual, as transgender, neither, or both.
Transitioning: Transman or transwoman who undergoes hormone replacement therapy (HRT) or sex reassignment surgery (SRS), or both. The definition of transition has broadened to include theories of psychological development or complementary methods of self-acceptance.
Genderqueer:Commonly used by someone who does not feel, identify/express themselves as either male or female, or any other socially constructed �norms� associated with their biological sex. Their gender identity/expression may change from man to woman and vice versa throughout their life. Genderqueer is an identity that falls anywhere between man/boy/male and woman/girl/female on the spectrum of gender identities -  bi-gender, pan-gender, gender-fluid, or a-gender

title: Violence against Children- Physical, Emotional and Sexual Abuse
desc:
This violence against a minor of any gender can be done by family members, relatives and neighbours or by institutions for education and in the case of a child. 
1. Physical abuse: Includes bruises, bite, burn, punctures, laceration, hair pulling, hematoma, internal organ damage, subdural hematoma etc.
2. Emotional abuse: insult, terrorizing, spurning, isolating etc. neglect: nutritional, education, medical, clothing etc.
3. Sexual abuse: Includes touching and non-touching activity. Some examples of touching activity include:
- Touching a child's genitals or private parts for sexual stimulation
- Making a child touch someone else's genitals, play sexual games or have sex putting objects or body parts (like fingers, tongue or penis) inside the vagina, in the mouth or in the anus of a child for sexual stimulation. See rape and statutory rape.
Sometimes there is violent use of children to punish an adult.  
Some examples of non-touching activity include:
- Showing pornography to a child
- Deliberately exposing an adult's genitals to a child
- Photographing a child in sexual poses
- Encouraging a child to watch or hear sexual acts
- Inappropriately watching a child undress or use the bathroom

title: Violence against women
desc: Violence against women Or VAW, also known interchangeable known as Gender Based Violence, are collectively, violent acts that are primarily or exclusively committed against women. There is no consent to this form of violence by any women. Often VAW is considered a hate crime, as a result of misogyny, patriarchy and often willing matriarchy.  This type of violence targets a specific group with the victim's gender, usually girl or woman, as a primary motive. This type of violence is gender-based, meaning that the acts of violence are committed against women expressly because they are women. Many harmful traditional practices are now criminalised and liable to punishment if reported.

title: Violent Use of Children
desc: Some abusive acts are directed against or involve children in order to control or punish the adult victim (e.g., physical attacks against a child, sexual use of children, forcing children to watch the abuse of the survivor, engaging children in the abuse of the survivor). A perpetrator may use children to maintain control over his partner by not paying child support, requiring the children to spy, requiring that at least one child always be in the company of the survivor, threatening to take children away from her, involving her in long legal fights over custody, or kidnapping or taking the children hostage as a way to force the survivor�s compliance. Children are also drawn into the assaults and are sometimes injured simply because they are present (e.g., the victim is holding an infant when pushed against the wall) or because the child attempts to intervene in the fight.

title: Virgin
desc: a person who has never had sexual intercourse of any kind either heterosexual or homosexual.

title: Virginity testing
desc: A virginity test is the practice and process of determining whether a person, usually a girl or woman, is a virgin; i.e., whether she has never engaged in sexual intercourse. The test typically involves a check for the presence of an intact hymen, on the assumption that it can only be torn as a result of sexual intercourse. Virginity testing is widely considered controversial, both because of its implications for the tested girls and women and because it is viewed as unethical in developed societies.
